respondent.name: LUIS M. SANCHEZ VALLE, ET AL.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 15-1808, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico v. Valle. Mr. Landau.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Landau, could Congress amend U.S.C. 1704, which covers Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa? Could it amend that statute and put Puerto Rico in there as well?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: In -- in the statute is -- it works both ways.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But is there -- is there --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What -- what about the Northern Marianas?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Landau, could you finish your answer to my question? You said yes, as far as what the federal Congress can deal with, what the federal prosecutors do, but the statute works both ways. Are you saying it couldn't -- Congress has no power to do that with respect to Puerto Rico?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You're saying it's a hard question, but you haven't given me --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Just take the statute as it is. Just add Puerto Rico --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- not telling prosecutors what to do in a particular case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That doesn't mean it couldn't. That doesn't mean it couldn't change the law. Is it essential to your case that we recognize Puerto Rico as a sovereign?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's our usual double Alderson Reporting Company jeopardy law, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- two sovereigns, it's a different matter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, I don't understand how that helps you, Mr. Landau. You're saying that the test is what the source of authority is, and you're saying that the source of authority here is the Puerto Rican people.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But that seems to be just -- Alderson Reporting Company you're not taking another step back. What's the source of authority of Puerto Rican people? The source of authority of Puerto Rican people was a Congressional act. If you go back, the ultimate source of authority is Congress.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, but Congress today, if it felt like it -- and of course it won't. But if it felt like it, could Congress go back on that decision?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, suppose we assume that Congress could rescind the existing compact.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Do you then lose your case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Are there -- you know, "sovereignty" is a slippery word. That's why the framers didn't use it in the constitution. Alderson Reporting Company Are you suggesting there's kind of a second class sovereignty and a first class sovereignty?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Landau, we have a situation as a result of the decision of the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico. I think it was two of the justices who said we're not going to get into this business about the Constitution. We think, interpreting our own double jeopardy provision, somebody should not be tried a second time. So that's going to be the law of Puerto Rico. That's -- if the Puerto Rico Supreme Court said that, then we would have the situation that has led us to grant cert in this case. That is, if you have a prosecution first in the Federal government, then Puerto Rico will not have a second prosecution. You have it first in Puerto Rico. The Federal government is free to institute a second prosecution.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And they could. They could. If -- if the -- if we told the majority you're wrong, nothing would prevent them from agreeing with those two justices, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Then there's no way you could break that situation of having -- it depends on which -- which jurisdiction goes first.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Landau, there's something you said that resonates with me, 'cause I've been trying to find a definition of "sovereignty." And one has been created in the briefing by saying that states are sovereign; yet if you look at international usage, they wouldn't consider states necessarily Alderson Reporting Company sovereign because they can't order their foreign affairs. They can't print money. They can't do lots of things that others would consider them sovereign for. So I guess the Constitution does something else with that word. What is it -- what are the elements of sovereignty with respect to the Double Jeopardy Clause that you think are commanded by our case law? There -- there's more than just the Puerto Rican people say.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And it can't be that it's the compact alone. So what is it? What are the principles --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- that you meet that would create sovereignty in the Double Jeopardy sense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Now, I'm looking at Lanza, and it says -- I think Lanza says, and it's a Double Jeopardy --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- Clause, that for Double Jeopardy Clause purposes, sovereignty means, one, that the separate entity possesses the authority to determine what shall be an -- an offense against their peace and dignity; two, can enact laws without the interference of the other; and, three, draws authorities to punish the offender -- and this is the one that you've been arguing -- from a distinct source of power from the other sovereign.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And -- and you keep saying it's the Constitution. It's the "We the People." It sounds a -- a bit histrionic to me. It -- there's something else. What is meant -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- by this distinct source of power?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Landau, I thought that, in the -- in the case of the Indian Tribes, what -- what the Court said is they were once sovereign before we got here and we took some of that sovereignty away. Alderson Reporting Company That's not the case with Puerto Rico.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the rationale was that the tribes had this sovereignty, and that's what was being respected.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, what is it? That is, look. If we simply write an opinion and it says, Puerto Rico is sovereign, that has enormous implications.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The insular cases are Alderson Reporting Company totally changed in their applications.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The political implications I'll just stay away from. On the other hand, if we write an opinion that says it's just a territory, that has tremendous implications.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: How did we tell the UN it wasn't a colony? Why are we not reporting on this colony every year?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So either way, between those two, the implications in law and in politics and everything else are overwhelming. Therefore, you argue a third and middle position. Your position pointing to four cases in this Court, so you have very good authority. It's for Double Jeopardy purposes. There is a different question. The question is what are the sources of the law? And then I find four cases that say just what you said. Okay? Now, you say the sources of the law, the sources of criminal law here are different. Okay. What I think Justice Sotomayor wanted you to say is explain that. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Take a little time, if you like. In what way are they different?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Going back to the political issues. And --  and --  and that's what I think Justice Breyer is trying to stay away from. This is a very simple question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right? Can the Federal government override a Puerto Rican law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Can they --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Can they veto a Puerto Rican law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Who makes these laws?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The laws were made by Puerto Rico's comparable Congress.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Even in saying that, Mr. Landau, you're putting Congress in the driver's seat here: It was done at the invitation of Congress. Congress approved it. Presumably Congress can unapprove it if Congress ever wished to. So if Congress is in the driver's seat, why isn't Congress the source of authority for the purposes of our Double Jeopardy jurisprudence --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: --  which seems to make that the issue? I mean, you can imagine a different Double Jeopardy jurisprudence where the issue was who just exercises authority in the real world? But that seems not to be what we ask.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Let -- let's call this -- this theory of yours interim sovereignty. Are there any examples in international law of interim sovereignty? Are there any examples in international law or in the United States' experience of a dichotomy such as you suggest?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I -- I -- I just don't know the answer to that.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why does that --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why does --  why does the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico have that authority? Where did it come from?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But it had complete authority under the Territorial Clause whether to do that or not, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So that would -- I --  it would seem to me, then, that the authority to do it came from Congress when they passed the --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: --  the law authorizing Puerto Rico to adopt a Constitution of its own.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why is --  I mean, you seem to fix on invited as somehow different than authorized.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Aren't there territorial legislatures?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What's the difference?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why -- why can't you say the laws they enact have as their source the -- the people of the territory?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: May I just ask you a question about that? I don't quite understand because this -- this whole issue is a result of a five-to-four decision of this Court in the 1950s, right? Bartkus.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Bartkus.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So -- so talking about cases before that, there was just -- there was no issue before that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Recognized how, because this was -- it was a very close case, as you know.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And so I don't think it was settled before then.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I'm questioning you looking back before the Bartkus case, for precedent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Landau, I'm not sure you answered my question about why territorial legislatures are different.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If you say that the issue is the source of the law in question, it seems to me that the territorial legislature is as much the source of a law as is the legislature of Puerto Rico.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I see your -- I see your time is getting up. It seemed to me that in a way, if you answered Justice Scalia's question, well, yes, it is -- it is true that local legislature is the source of the law, and there is Double Jeopardy there too. Yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Unikowsky.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: It does seem, Mr. Unikowsky, as if Congress has given Puerto Rico as much authority Alderson Reporting Company as it possibly could have short of making it a State itself. Do you disagree with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What kind of territory is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: There is. The -- the insular cases have at least two.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay. So it's that kind.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, what is Estado Libre Asociado?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no. I just wonder as it appears in the Constitution of Puerto Rico.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The alternative of the word Commonwealth.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I just wonder what it is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Where does it say in the Constitution that Congress cannot? After all, Congress can admit a State. It says that specifically.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Talks about territories. So you're saying Congress and the President too do not have the authority to associate with some other entity under the form of Estado Libre Asociado?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Where does it say that in any of our cases?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And what are the Indians?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because -- because we do not recognize explicitly in the Constitution "Commonwealth," therefore there is no Commonwealth? Is that what you want us to say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: With some purposes. But the -- the issue here, as I see it -- which maybe will take a second -- is there are four cases that say we don't have to reach these grand questions. All we have to do is decide what the source of power is. Now their argument is that even if you go back to the Foraker Act, which indeed did have the people of Puerto Rico making laws, and if you then add the Resolution which delegated the authority to make the Constitution, the Constitution itself which speaks of "We the People" of Puerto Rico making a law, the fact that later Congress and the President said Puerto Rico has a Republican form of government, the fact that subsequent to that we went to the United Nations and had them withdraw the requirement to report on a colony because Puerto Rico is not a colony -- - and you know the words as well as I, and they sure sound like "sovereign." Alderson Reporting Company And in Valle, which no one mentions, Trias Monge wrote that in fact all these laws -- and he was talking about civil, but I suppose it applies to Commonwealth too -- are to be interpreted in light of the civil code tradition of Europe, which was the tradition that applied prior to 1900, and not the common law. I don't see, when you put all those things together, if you're looking at the facts of what the law of Puerto Rico is in the area, it sounds to me like it's civil code coming out of a constitution which I grant you was given by authority of Congress. So there we are. Now five things they've listed there that make it different, not only from anything you can think of but from anything I can think of. So why don't you reply to those five things, if you want.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Take your time. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But that was not true of many of the territories that were admitted as States. They came in to Statehood and were conferred by a -- the sovereignty was conferred by a -- agreement with the Federal government. And States were admitted by agreement, and sovereignty were confirmed on them by agreement. And so are you telling me that if -- let's say one of the islands in the Caribbean. I'll make one Alderson Reporting Company up. Okay? Atlantis has been --  never kicked out its foreign colonial status years ago, but it really doesn't have many resources. And it comes to the United States and it says, I want a treaty. You'll take care of all of our external affairs. We'll follow whatever you say with respect to external affairs. We're even going to use the American dollar 'cause it's convenient, but you can't touch our internal affairs. And Congress approves that treaty. Would that, for Double Jeopardy purposes, not be a sovereign?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I couldn't hear. Would or wouldn't?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But if Congress has that treaty power, why does it have similar power under its Rule and Regulation Clause of the Constitution? There's no limiting principle of what rules and regulations Congress can make.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Under that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The Indians. What about the Indians?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Unikowsky, it sure seems as though in the early 1950s, Congress with respect to Puerto Rico, said we want to give it some sovereign authority. We want to give it an enormous amount of Home Rule authority, basically everything, and we also have some idea in our heads that Puerto Rico ought to be a sovereign with all the things sovereigns have like a Constitution and a "We the People" clause. And -- and why isn't that something -- it's -- it's an unusual idea, to be sure, a -- a sovereign territory. But Congress seems to have wanted to do exactly that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And is -- is our argument so abstract that it doesn't acknowledge real practicalities of multiple prosecutions? Of -- of course Mr. Landau couldn't come up and say, please forget Heath and Wheeler and Walter and Grafton. Let's do something other than sovereignty. Has there been any suggestion by Alderson Reporting Company commentators and so forth that this whole inquiry of sovereignty and source of power is a little bit misplaced? Of course, you have the problem with the cities within its -- within separate -- within one State, which is, it seems, ought to be subject to a single rule. But have there been any commentaries that lead us to another approach altogether? I don't think we're going to overrule four cases, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Unikowsky, you -- you said before that Congress didn't mean to confer sovereignty here. Do you think Congress could do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry. You -- you're saying to me that Congress can't make Puerto Rico independent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So if it can do that, why can't it have other arrangements with Puerto Rico the way it has with everybody else? Why are we saying that with respect to territories they don't have that power?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: We need to. I mean, we told the UN, this doesn't sound like we said it was a municipality.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: UN said that Puerto Rico has been invested with the attributes of political sovereignty, which clearly identify the status of self-government attained by the Puerto Rican people.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Who said this? This is the UN?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: This is what we told the UN. We told the UN that -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And on the basis of that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Who --  who is "we"? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's --  what it says here --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Who's we?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It consists of the President of the United States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The President said that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Or his delegate. His delegate. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We need to involve counsel in the dialogue. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I --  I have. You've read the same thing. There are about ten words such as "republic," "not a colony," "attributes of political sovereignty," repeated in five or six key documents. I do --  not everyone does --  happen to think that what we tell the UN to get it removed from the colony status bears some consideration. I grant you not everyone agrees with that, but that's my view of it. Laughter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. And I guess I --  all right. Forget it. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You said it was like a municipality. I just think that having the attributes of political sovereignty, and being a republic, and saying that the Constitution of Puerto Rico is the basic document, whatever the language was there, don't sound like a municipality.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You think that doesn't have meaning? In most municipalities, their offenses are treated as criminal offenses and not criminal infractions. They can only pass laws with respect to a very limited amount of issues. The States have control over many, many other things. They are substantially different. Why would we have bothered talking about the structure of Florida's system with municipalities in Waller? We went through how the State controlled all of the --  most of the internal affairs of municipalities, and we said they are not separate sovereigns because of this control. All we could have said is what you want us to say now, which is municipalities' ultimate source is the State government. But we did something very different in that case.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Briefly.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Ms. Saharsky.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry. They haven't issued that. In all of those cases, Grafton and all of the ones pre-1952, the Court pointed to the fact that, when these islands pass laws, they could be vetoed by Congress or --  or were --  that was the Organic Act. In all of these places, Congress was appointing their legislature, in part, or they were appointing colonial governors. And we went through, in each one of them, very carefully, what the issues of control that remained, that didn't make them sovereign in any way, that made them classic territories. So it's not that we didn't --  we eschewed looking at that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But you forget that Congress could veto those laws.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Before 1952, Congress could veto Puerto Rico's laws. It has relinquished that right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, now, this is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: --  gives plenary power to Alderson Reporting Company Congress.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: This is -- it's very interesting what you're saying. Remember, though, one of the provisions of the Puerto Rico Constitution, which Congress approved and said it was a Republican form of government, is that criminal actions shall be conducted in the name and by the authority of the people of Puerto Rico. Now, that sounds like a delegation of authority as to source, to go back to the Spanish system if they want. Now, if I take your view, then I guess you have to say -- and it has considerable implication -- that that doesn't matter because Congress can take back what they gave. Now, is that the position of the government or the executive branch? Because that has tremendous implication.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because obviously, there is an argument as to whether what Congress and the President gave in Resolution 600, followed by the Constitution, followed by what happened at the UN, under the authority -- and looking to Felix Frankfurter for guidance, who said that the Constitution provides us Alderson Reporting Company with many forms of possible relationship. That's what his view was. And now, is the position of the executive branch -- I mean, you want to take a position on this? That -- that -- that Congress, if it wishes, can take all of that back and Puerto Rico has no more independence than -- in principle, than any of the other places that were territories? Now, that's -- that's a big question. But do -- do you -- do you see it's an important question? And I want to know if the government's position rests upon it, because that's -- that's an important statement for the executive, in my opinion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But there are some things --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Let's go back to the insular cases right there. There are different kinds of territories. It's because of that that Frankfurter says that the Constitution has left the field of invention open. The Alderson Reporting Company decisions in the insular cases mean this, if they mean anything: That there's nothing in the Constitution to hamper the responsibility of Congress in working out arrangements. Now, if that's so, why couldn't Congress delegate, without the power to take it back, the authority to Puerto Rico to work out its own criminal code subject to the constraints of the Bill of Rights, et cetera? Why couldn't it? I mean, if Frankfurter is right. Or do you take the opposite position, that it couldn't?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Do you think it's not possible, Ms. Saharsky -- I mean, putting aside whether Congress has done it here, but you think it's simply not possible for Congress to confer sovereignty in the sense Alderson Reporting Company that would matter for the Double Jeopardy Clause?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But -- but -- but not short of that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Suppose Congress could also Alderson Reporting Company say, could it not, that --  in its criminal code, that if a crime has been prosecuted and under Puerto Rican law it will not be --  the same --  the same crime will not be prosecuted under Federal law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Couldn't it say that if it wanted to?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No --  well, but --  no, certainly Congress cannot --  cannot deny double jeopardy effect to something that would be double jeopardy, but I'm talking about a statute that says, even though it might have double jeopardy effect, we say --  we say no.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, it's not a matter of what the Fifth Amendment permits. Congress just says, we will -- the Justice Department will not prosecute a crime that has already been prosecuted in -- in Puerto Rico.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, no, I understand that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm just saying, if you like that result, it can be done by the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm trying to be helpful. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Could you explain before you sit down when and why the United States changed its position on this question? Because as I understand it, in --  in more than one brief, took the position that Puerto Rico, for double jeopardy cases, is --  for the Double Jeopardy Clause is --  is treated like a State.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Four minutes, Mr. Landau.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Landau, would you explain what "estado libre asociado" means in Spanish?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Literally.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Do you know why they didn't use that phrase in the compact with the United States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I believe, because I've seen the Act, that they didn't because States have a different meaning in the United States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The Solicitor General's office claims that Grafton says that when we're looking at double jeopardy, we're looking at something different. We're looking at territory versus state. Do you agree with that reading of the Shell case and of Grafton?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And how about Shell?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
